sentences.sentence: I had now been on this unhappy island for over ten months.
All possibility of escape from this situation seemed to be gone.
I firmly believed that no human had ever set foot upon( 进入 ) that place.
Having now made my shelter( 住所 ), I wanted to explore the island.
It was on the 15th of July that I began to take a closer look at the island itself.
I found a little stream that led inward( 向内 ) towards the center of the island, and followed it until there were more trees.
In this area I found many melons( 甜瓜 ) upon the ground, and grapes upon the trees.
The vines( 葡萄藤 ) had spread over the trees, and the grapes were just now very ripe( 成熟的 ) and rich.
I decided to dry them in the sun, and keep them as dried grapes or raisins( 葡萄干 ) are kept.
I also saw many parrots( 鹦鹉 ), and if I had been able to I would have caught one, and taught it to speak to me.
I did, after some difficulty, catch a young parrot( 鹦鹉 ), after knocking him down with a stick.
I named him Poll. It took me some years before I could make him speak.
In the night, I climbed up in a tree, where I slept well.
The next morning I went on, traveling nearly four miles.
I found an opening( 空地 ) that led to the sea, on the other side of the island from my shelter( 住所 ).
I could see the sea to the west, and beyond it, some land.
I could not tell whether it was an island or a continent, but by my guess it could not be less than fifteen or twenty miles off.
I knew it must be part of America.
I considered that if this land was the Spanish coast, I would certainly, at one time or another, see a ship pass by.
If not, then it was the savage( 荒凉的 ) coast between the Spanish country and the Brazils.
The people who live there are man-eaters, and murder and eat all the humans that they find.
At the end of this long walk I came to an opening, where a little spring of fresh water ran due( 正向，正对着（东、南、西、北） ) east.
The country appeared fresh, green, and fruitful.
I saw here many cocoa, orange, and lemon trees.
The lemons that I gathered were pleasant to eat, and I mixed their juice afterwards( 后来 ) with water, which made it very cool and refreshing( 提神的 ).
I gathered a great heap( 堆 ) of grapes in one place, and a great parcel of lemons in another place, and taking a few of each with me, I traveled home.
During this return journey, my dog caught a young goat, and seized upon it.
I ran in to take hold of it, caught it, and saved it alive from the dog.
I wanted to bring it home, if I could, and so raise a tame( 驯服的 ) goat, which might supply me when my gunpowder( 火药 ) was all used up.
I made a collar for this little creature, and led him along, till I came to my cave.
When I came home from this journey, I thought with great pleasure of the fruitfulness of that valley, and the security from storms on that side of the water.
I began to consider moving my shelter( 住所 ), and looking out for a place in that pleasant, fruitful part of the island.
But thinking more deeply about it, I realized that I was now by the seaside, where it was at least possible that something might happen to my advantage.
And I cannot express how happy I felt to come back to my old cave, for this little wandering journey had been so tiring to me.
So, upon second thoughts( 经再次考虑 ), I decided not to move, but I built a little kind of a cottage on that side of the island.
I surrounded( 包围 ) it at a distance with a double fence, as high as I could reach.
I was happy that now I had my country house, and my sea-coast house.
This work took me up to the beginning of August.
I had just finished my fence, and began to enjoy my work, when the rains came, and I returned to my first shelter( 住所 ).
I had made a tent like the other for my cottage, from a piece of a sail, and spread it very well.
But I did not have the shelter( 住所 ) of a hill there to keep me from storms, nor a cave behind me to go back into when the rains were very heavy.
On the 3rd of August I found the grapes I had hung up perfectly dried, so I began to take them down from the trees.
It was very lucky that I did so, for the rains which followed would have spoiled( 毁掉 ) them, and I would have lost most of my winter food.
I had over two hundred large bunches( 串 ) of them.
No sooner had I taken them all down, and carried most of them home to my cave, than it began to rain.
From the 14th of August to the 26th, it rained constantly, so that I could not go out of my cave.
I was now very careful not get too wet.
During this time when the rain kept me inside, I worked daily two or three hours at making my cave bigger.
By the time the rain stopped, I had come to the outside of the hill, and made a door or way out.
September the 30th.—Today was the unhappy anniversary( 周年纪念日 ) of my landing.
I looked at the lines I had carved( 雕刻 ) on my post, and found I had been on shore three hundred and sixty-five days.
I kept this day as a sacred day, setting it aside for religious practice.
I threw myself on the ground with the most serious shame, praying and confessing( 忏悔 ) my sins( 罪过 ) to God.
Not having tasted any food for twelve hours, I then ate a biscuit-cake and a bunch( 串 ) of grapes, and went to bed.
I had all this time observed no Sabbath day( 安息日 ), so I set apart every seventh day for a Sabbath( 安息日 ).
A little after this, my ink began to run out.
I contented myself to use it more sparingly, and to write down only the most remarkable events of my life.
It was now that I began noticeably to feel how much happier this life I now led was, than the evil( 罪恶的 ) life I had led in the past.
I gave sincere( 由衷的 ) thanks to God, that He had shown me it was possible to be happy in this lonely condition, more than I would have been in the liberty( 自由 ) of society.
Before, as I walked about, the pain of my soul at my condition would break out upon me suddenly.
My very heart would die within me, to think of the situation I was in, and how I was trapped in an empty wilderness( 荒野 ).
But now I began to change my way of thinking.
I daily read the Bible( 圣经 ), and applied all the comforts of it to my present state.
One morning, being very sad, I opened the Bible( 圣经 ) upon these words, “I will never leave you, nor abandon( 抛弃 ) you!”
“Well, then,” said I, “if God does not abandon( 抛弃 ) me, what does it matter if the world abandons( 抛弃 ) me?
If I had all the world, and lost the favor and blessing of God, could there be any comparison in the loss?”
With this thought I was going to give thanks to God for bringing me to this place, but something shocked my mind at that thought, and I dared not speak the words.
“How can you become such a hypocrite( 伪君子 ),” said I, even aloud, “to pretend to be thankful for a situation which you pray to be saved from?” So I stopped there.
But though I could not say I thanked God for being there, yet I sincerely( 真诚地 ) gave thanks to God, for opening my eyes to see the former condition of my life.
